item.title: Beocord 9000: Replacing the RAM Battery
item.description: The Beocord 9000 utilizes a 3V battery to power its 16-word memory chip, an MCM144102, which is described as a peripheral memory unit in the Motorola 6804 manual but lacks readily available detailed specifications. This chip is responsible for storing calibration data and potentially the system time, although further investigation is required. A visual representation of the circuit is included below. A positive aspect of the design is the inclusion of diode D27, which safeguards the battery against reverse polarity connection.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Replacing the RPM Indicator Light Bulbs with LEDs
item.description: During the restoration of a Beogram 4002 (5513), the incandescent bulbs in the RPM indicator panels were replaced with LED-based alternatives. This change aimed to enhance the stability of the DC motor control system by reducing heat generation, a common issue with traditional bulbs. The new SMD LED circuits, designed for a seamless drop-in replacement, feature red and green LEDs calibrated to mimic the warm glow of incandescent lighting. This spectrum, especially the inclusion of red photons, ensures accurate illumination of the red plastic RPM indicators.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Restoration of the Arm Lowering Mechanism, Replacement of Tracking Sensor Light Bulb with a LED Assembly, and a New Aluminum Pulley
item.description: My Beogram 4000 arrived damaged from shipping, so I began by fixing it. The carriage, which moves along a rod with bearings, had detached. I took out the rod and bearings to put them back into the carriage correctly. Then, I used a wrench to secure them. This allowed me to reinstall the carriage. Next, I started my usual restoration process, beginning with the arm lowering mechanism. I took apart the solenoid, damper, connecting parts, and springs.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5521): Replacing the Tracking Sensor Light Bulb with a SMD LED
item.description: The Beogram 4002 I’m currently working on had a faulty tracking sensor light bulb. To fix it, I used my custom-designed SMD LED replacement part, which is a direct swap for the original bulb housing. This component was recently updated during a Beogram 4000 restoration to incorporate an integrated intensity trimmer. This trimmer simplifies the process of adjusting the tracking sensor feedback significantly. It enables fine-tuning after the light sensors are mechanically positioned below the light source.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5523): Restoration of the Arm Lowering and Tracking Systems
Beogram 4002 (5513): Complete Restoration and Test Drive with Cal Tjader and Claus Ogerman
item.description: I recently began restoring a Beogram 4002 (Type 5513) turntable for an Australian customer who purchased it on eBay. The turntable arrived in poor condition. My initial evaluation is documented here. This post details the unit’s restoration, excluding the dust cover, which will be covered separately. I began with the DC platter motor, as is customary, since the bearing lubrication process requires a few days. Here’s the motor after removal:

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Sensor Arm Light Bulb
item.description: During the restoration of my Beogram 4002 (5513), I inspected the sensor arm light bulb and was surprised to find it in perfect condition. Unlike other bulbs I’ve encountered, which typically display a dark film on the glass due to filament evaporation, this one was spotless: This suggests that this particular Beogram was either lightly used or had its bulb replaced previously. As a result, I will not change it. However, the bulb’s placement within its compartment is worth noting.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Full Functional Restoration and Installation of Beolover Commander Remote
item.description: This document details the restoration of a Beogram 4002 (Type 5513) turntable. Initial assessment of the unit can be found on a separate blog post. The restoration began with the platter motor, as its bearings require a lengthy oil treatment. The motor was extracted, disassembled, and its bearings were submerged in oil under a vacuum to allow for optimal oil diffusion. Concurrently, the carriage assembly was cleaned. All “motion critical” parts, including the arm and its associated mechanisms, were removed, ultrasonically cleaned, and reassembled.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): RPM Trimmer Illumination Very Low
item.description: After reviving the circuit boards of a Beogram 4002 (5513) turntable, I focused on improving the dim backlighting of the 33 and 45 RPM adjustment scales. I removed the panel containing these adjustments for easier access. Taking off the light covers revealed the bulbs. A closer look showed that the bulbs were not the correct type, leading to the weak illumination. I replaced these bulbs with my custom-designed SMD LED replacements.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Complete Restoration Including a Refurbished Keypad and Commander Remote Control Module
item.description: This unit is currently for sale. Please, see here. This post details the complete restoration of a Beogram 4002 (5513) from Arizona, which I first inspected as shown here. The unit’s condition upon arrival is pictured below: My first step, as always, was to initiate oil infusion for the platter motor bearings. Here’s the motor after removal: I took it apart to extract the bearings (two small rings on the black pad):

item.title: Beogram 4000: Completing the Restoration and a Test Spin with Weather Report!
item.description: This Beogram 4000 restoration project is complete, and it’s time to review the work. Two previous posts covered specific repairs: addressing a missing transistor insulator and a faulty motor driver transistor, and creating a 3D printed replacement for the fragile MMC cartridge mounts. This post summarizes the remaining restoration work. Typically, the process begins with a complete overhaul of the turntable’s carriage. This involves disassembling and cleaning all moving parts, such as the arm lowering mechanism.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Keypad Restoration and LEDs for the RPM Indicators
item.description: The Beogram 4002 (5513) I’m currently working on had a significantly deteriorated keypad. The material used for these keypads tends to wear down over time due to the oils from fingerprints, making them a known weak point in this model. My friend in Denmark, who sadly passed away recently, was an expert at restoring these keypads. In his memory, I’ve been trying to learn his techniques. A couple of months ago, I started practicing, and I managed to successfully restore one keypad.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Replacing the RPM Scales Light Bulbs with LEDs and a Further Improvement of the RPM Stability
item.description: During the restoration of a Beogram 4002 (5513), SMD LEDs were used to replace the incandescent bulbs that illuminate the RPM trimmer scales on the control panel. This modification involved using replacement boards that could be directly soldered onto the existing light bulb solder points. Images of the replacement boards and the installed LEDs are provided. These LED assemblies are available to other interested individuals. A video demonstrating the installation process is also available.

item.title: Beogram 4002: Replacing the RPM Indicator Bulbs with SMD LEDs
item.description: I’m currently restoring a Beogram 4002 (5513) and have been systematically replacing its lightbulbs. Today’s focus was the RPM indicator, which allowed me to refine my LED replacement method. Previously, I detailed a process using red and green LEDs from an RGB through-hole 5mm LED to replace the incandescent bulbs. While somewhat successful, the backlighting of the RPM trimmer scales lacked uniformity. Standard through-hole LEDs emit light directionally, requiring me to sand their bulbs for a matte finish and paint the tops black to minimize uneven brightness.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5523): Complete Functional Restoration and Installation of Commander Remote Control System
item.description: This article details the restoration process of a Beogram 4002 (5523) turntable, aiming for like-new performance. The restoration began with addressing the DC platter motor, a common area of concern in these models. The motor was carefully removed and disassembled, and its bearings, often found dry, underwent a revitalization process. This involved immersing them in motor oil and applying a vacuum to draw out air and facilitate oil penetration. Simultaneously, the carriage and arm-lowering mechanisms were cleaned and re-lubricated.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5501): Restoration of RPM Trimmer Panel
item.description: Following the PCB rebuild of a Beogram 4002 (5501) turntable, the author focused on restoring the RPM trimmer panel, which had been previously replaced due to a burned-out illumination bulb. The first step involved re-soldering the connections where the original panel had been cut off and adding heat-shrink tubing for protection. LED replacement boards, specifically designed for the 550x series, were installed to provide similar resistance and current draw as the original bulbs.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (Type 5513): Full Functional Restoration
item.description: This blog post details the functional restoration of a Beogram 4002 (Type 5513) turntable from a client in Florida. A previous post documented the initial assessment of the unit. Upon beginning the restoration, the turntable was in relatively original condition. However, the platter motor showed signs of prior work, evidenced by an incorrectly installed pulley. To address this, the motor was removed and disassembled to extract and lubricate the bearings. This involved immersing them in motor oil under vacuum until air bubbles ceased to appear, indicating the bearings were properly saturated.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Rebuilding the Arm Lowering and Tracking Mechanisms, and Installation of a New Carriage Pulley
item.description: During the restoration of a Beogram 4002 (5513) turntable, the arm lowering and tracking mechanisms, often problematic due to hardened lubricants, required attention. While the lowering damper section was functional, the damper-to-arm linkage was stuck and only moved because its pin had loosened. The restoration process involved carefully disassembling the arm lowering mechanism, cleaning it, and applying fresh lubrication. The seized damper-to-arm linkage was removed, requiring a workbench procedure to press out its stuck pin.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5524): Full Functional Restoration and Installation of Beolover Commander Remote
item.description: This article details the restoration process of a Beogram 4002 turntable from Texas, following an initial assessment. The author mentions a slight delay due to relocating to Albuquerque. The turntable was mostly original, suggesting a straightforward restoration. The process began with the DC platter motor, which is typical for these units. After nearly 50 years of use, the motor’s Oilite bearings needed re-lubrication. This involved disassembling the motor, immersing the bearings in oil, and creating a vacuum to help the oil penetrate.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Restoration of the Keypad
item.description: Following the restoration of the Beogram 4000’s arm carriage, attention shifted to the keypad—the turntable’s control center housing the early digital control system. A single screw secures the keypad, allowing access to its internal components. Uniquely, this keypad lacked visible wiring underneath, unlike other 4000 models with wiring behind the latch. Instead, the wiring harness was cleverly routed into the pad from the front, simplifying reassembly. The restoration process began by addressing the fragile light bulbs illuminating the arm position scale and RPM trimmers.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Replacement of RPM Trimmer Panel Bulbs with LED Assemblies
item.description: Following the electronic restoration of a Beogram 4002 (5513) turntable, the next step was to upgrade the light bulbs in the RPM adjustment panel with LED assemblies. This change was made because LEDs offer greater longevity and produce less heat compared to incandescent bulbs. Reduced heat generation is particularly beneficial as it improves the stability of the DC motor responsible for driving the platter. The original RPM control panel, in a disassembled state, is depicted below.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Restoration of the Arm Lowering and Tracking Systems
item.description: My work began on the Beogram 4000 turntable that arrived from Germany. As is my practice, the tracking and arm lowering mechanisms were the first to be refurbished. The arm lowering mechanism, controlled by a solenoid and damper arrangement, is pictured here: After removing components requiring cleaning and lubrication, the area looked like this: Here are the disassembled parts: With cleaning and lubrication complete, reassembly followed. Next, I addressed the seized damper-to-arm linkage, accessible only after detaching the sensor arm.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Rebuilding the Arm Lowering Mechanism and Upgrade of the Tracking System with a LED Based Light Source
item.description: With the DC motor operating correctly, the restoration of the Beogram 4002 (5513) continued with the arm lowering mechanism and tracking feedback system. The arm lowering mechanism, consisting of a solenoid and damper, was disassembled, cleaned, and lubricated. This process involved removing the damper, linkages, retaining washer, and spring. Detailed videos illustrating the rebuilding process are available. After reassembly, the arms were meticulously aligned parallel to each other and the keypad edge.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Replacement of Sensor Arm Light Bulb with an LED
item.description: The last incandescent bulb in this Beogram 4000 restoration project was replaced with an LED. Located within the sensor arm, this particular LED presented the biggest challenge due to the tight space. The solution involved creating a custom flexible PCB equipped with a current limiting resistor and a bypass to mimic the higher energy draw of a traditional light bulb. This was necessary because the control system relies on the current to confirm the bulb’s functionality.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Restoration of Arm Lowering and Tracking Systems
item.description: My first step when restoring a Beogram 4002 turntable is to focus on the arm lowering and tracking mechanisms. The arm lowering mechanism often requires attention because hardened lubricants can hinder the solenoid and damper assemblies. To address this, I disassemble the mechanism. Once the solenoid and linkages are removed, I take the parts to my workbench for cleaning and re-lubrication. Next, I address the linkage connecting the damper plunger to the tonearm, as it can cause delays in arm lowering, particularly after storage.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5521): Replacing the RPM Scale Illumination Bulbs with SMD LEDs
item.description: Following the replacement of the tracking sensor’s light source, the next stage in restoring my Beogram 4002 (5521) involved addressing the incandescent bulbs within the RPM trimmer panel. The 33 RPM bulb had burned out, prompting the decision to replace both bulbs with custom-designed SMD LED assemblies. Recognizing the importance of a red light component for illuminating the red RPM indicators, red-green LEDs were chosen. While amber LEDs offer an incandescent-like aesthetic, their narrow wavelength distribution hinders their ability to effectively illuminate red surfaces.

item.title: Beocord 9000: Restoration of the Peak Program Meter with SMD LEDs (I)
item.description: While I’m waiting for a part for a Beocord 9000 cassette deck, I’ve started restoring another one with faulty displays. It seems cassettes are making a comeback! I’m even hoping for new tapes and maybe even a revival of the Sony Walkman II. This particular Beocord 9000 has a very dim display: [Image of dim display] The “Time Cal” bulb is also weak, a common issue. I began with the VU meter (or Peak Program Meter), as I haven’t refurbished this type before.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Power Supply and Replacing the Reservoir Capacitors with a 3D Printed Fixture
item.description: It seems Bang & Olufsen made two versions of the Beogram 4002 (5513) with different power supply setups, both designed with a possible CD4 upgrade in mind. The output board could be swapped for one with a pre-amplifier and CD4 decoder. One version powers the CD4 board directly from the main PCB’s 30V rail and uses a single 4000uF capacitor. My Beogram 4002 uses a separate power supply for the CD4 board, with its own transformer winding, bridge rectifier, and 1000uF capacitor.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Replacement of Sensor Arm Bulb with an LED Assembly
item.description: During the restoration of a Beogram 4002 turntable, the light bulb in the sensor arm, crucial for record detection, was replaced with a longer-lasting LED. To ensure compatibility with the turntable’s bulb detection circuit, which disables record detection if a bulb failure is detected, the LED assembly was designed to mimic the current draw of the original bulb. LEDs inherently use less current, so a parallel current path was added to the LED board to compensate.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5501): Replacement of End Groove Detection Light Bulb with an LED
item.description: Following the restoration of the Beogram 4002 (5501) RPM trimmer panel, the focus shifted to the malfunctioning end groove detection mechanism. This ingenious mechanism utilizes a light bulb, a photoresistor, and an encoder wheel acting as a pulley to detect when the carriage accelerates after the record’s final track. By identifying this movement, the mechanism reduces the return time to the home position for records with extended end grooves, such as 12" singles or certain LPs with shorter playtimes.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Replacing the Speed Indictor Light Bulbs with RGB LEDs
item.description: During the wait for a 3D-printed part for a Beogram 4002 turntable restoration, the author decided to upgrade its speed indicator lights. Using a method from a previous video, they replaced the incandescent bulbs with RGB LEDs for a more authentic look. The original setup with incandescent bulbs was documented before the upgrade. The new setup utilizes both the red and green diodes of an RGB LED for a natural appearance, addressing the issue of amber LEDs failing to illuminate red scale markers properly.

item.title: Beocord 9000: Restoration of the Peak Program Meter with SMD LEDs (III)
item.description: This article, the third in a series about restoring a Beocord 9000’s peak program meters (PPM), focuses on installing and calibrating the rebuilt PPM. The initial step involved switching the original current limiting resistors with values suitable for modern SMD LEDs. These LEDs are more efficient and brighter, requiring significantly larger resistors to match the original brightness. Testing showed that 470 Ohm and 330 Ohm resistors for red and green LEDs, respectively, produced slightly brighter output compared to the original 180 Ohm and 120 Ohm resistors.

item.title: Beocord 9000: Replacing the Incandescent Indicator Light Bulbs with SMD LEDs
item.description: During the restoration of a Beocord 9000, two indicator lights presented problems. One had a typical issue with a broken lead, while the other had become dim due to a deteriorating filament. To address this, I opted to use SMD LEDs as replacements, similar to a method I’ve used for Beomaster 8000 units, documented on my blog. This provides lasting stability and safeguards against potential shipping damage. However, the Beocord 9000 has more compact reflector housings compared to the Beomaster 8000, necessitating a redesign of the PCBs for the LEDs.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5523): Replacement of the RPM Trimmer Light Bulbs with LEDs
item.description: Following the PCB restoration of the Beogram 4002 (5523), the next step was to swap the RPM trimmer illumination bulbs with LEDs. This change enhances the Beogram’s long-term stability and the DC motor’s RPM consistency. The RPM trimmers are integral to the DC motor’s feedback circuit, which maintains a steady RPM. Incandescent bulbs generate heat, affecting the trimmers and potentially causing RPM fluctuations. The cooler-running LEDs effectively address this issue.

item.title: Beocord 9000: Restoration of the Peak Program Meter Scale Illumination
item.description: Even though the scale illumination light bulb was functioning in the Beocord 9000 display, my customer opted for a replacement to avoid any potential issues during shipping. This makes sense because these bulbs are fragile and prone to breaking, especially with rough handling. I prefer to replace all bulbs to prevent future problems. I performed this procedure before on a Beocord 9000 with a broken bulb, as documented on my blog.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5523): Replacing the Incandescent Light Bulbs of the RPM Trimmer Scales with LEDs
item.description: During my current restoration of a Beogram 4002 (5523), I replaced the incandescent bulbs that light up the RPM trimmer adjustment scales. I swapped them with custom-designed SMD LED assemblies for longer-lasting illumination, which is beneficial for those aiming to use their Beogram long-term. Here’s a look at the latest iteration of the LED boards before installation: Fellow enthusiasts can acquire these assemblies. This video demonstrates the LED board installation process, starting with removing the trimmer panel and its existing light bulbs:

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Restoration of Arm Lowering and Tracking System
item.description: My work began with the Beogram 4002’s arm lowering and tracking mechanisms, as is customary for me. My client had already addressed the cleaning and lubrication of the damper and solenoid linkages, so my task was to detach the linkage connecting the damper and tonearm. This required removing the sensor arm assembly, as shown here: Extracting the sensor arm involved removing two screws at its base: The linkage could then be detached:

item.title: Beocord 9000: Exchanging the Rubber Parts in the Tape Mechanism
item.description: My Beocord 9000 restoration project saw some good progress. I recently installed new rubber tires on the idler wheels of the tape drive mechanism to address a rewinding issue. The deck wasn’t rewinding smoothly, becoming very slow and sometimes even stopping at the end of the process. This seemed like a common problem attributed to hardened idler wheel rubber, as suggested by Beoworld.org. However, upon disassembling the mechanism, I discovered that a previous repair attempt had damaged a crucial friction pad, which was the root cause of the problem.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Replacing the Tracking Sensor Incandescent Bulb with a Drop-In SMD LED Assembly and a Peek at the Opto-Resistors
item.description: The tracking sensor bulb in my Beogram 4000 recently burned out. This was the fourth bulb to fail. I decided to use this opportunity to install my new SMD LED replacement assembly. This assembly uses efficient white LEDs at low power for longevity, likely exceeding 50 years. It also reduces the unit’s energy consumption by a few watts, lessening the load on the aging transformer. Details about the assembly and adjustments can be found in this video.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Complete Functional Restoration
item.description: Some time ago, a customer in Texas purchased a Beogram 4000 turntable on eBay from a seller in New York. The turntable was in fair condition, as detailed on the blog (see hyperlink). To address a cracked corner on the dust cover, the decision was made to acquire a second Beogram 4000, allowing the creation of one flawless unit from the two. With the arrival of the second turntable, the restoration began.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Replacing the Tracking Sensor Light Bulb with a Plug-In Ready SMD LED Assembly
item.description: During the restoration of my Beogram 4002 (5513), I installed the latest iteration of my SMD LED light source for the tracking sensor. Previously, I designed a drop-in SMD LED assembly to replace the incandescent bulb fixture, which worked well. However, it still relied on the original, cumbersome tracking sensor sensitivity adjustment process. This process involves carefully positioning the light sensors relative to the light source, a task made difficult by the mechanism’s sensitivity and the adjustment mechanism’s coarseness.

item.title: Beogram 4002: Replacing the Detector Arm Light Bulb with a LED
item.description: During the restoration of a Beogram 4002 turntable, a replacement was needed for the detector arm light bulb. The previous repair attempt had left the assembly in poor condition, with damaged wiring and a misaligned photo cell. To find a suitable replacement, a well-preserved Beogram 4004 was used for comparison. Given the scarcity of original bulbs and the desire for a long-lasting solution, a 3mm LED was chosen as the replacement.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5503): Complete Functional Restoration
item.description: This document details the refurbishment process of a Beogram 4002 (Type 5503) turntable with an AC motor. The unit was received from a customer in Oklahoma, and an initial evaluation was documented previously here. Upon arrival, the unit was partially disassembled, revealing its internal components. One of the first tasks involved addressing a loose spring in the shut-off switch, which was successfully reinserted to restore functionality. The restoration began with the carriage assembly.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Replacement of the Incandescent Bulb in the Sensor Arm with an LED
item.description: To ensure stability after restoring Beograms, I like to test them thoroughly. While playing records on a recently revived Beogram 4000, the sensor arm’s light bulb burned out. This presented a chance to modify my LED assembly design, previously used for the Beogram 4002, to fit the Beogram 4000. The redesigned Kapton flex board can be folded to fit the sensor arm bulb cavity: A 3D-printed wedge, attached to the back, positions the LED for optimal light reflection into the arm’s sensor.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5523): Rebuilding the Arm Lowering Mechanism, and Tracking Sensor Bulb Replacement and Adjustment
item.description: The initial step for restoring a Beogram 4002 turntable typically involves reconditioning the arm lowering mechanism and calibrating the tracking system. In this instance, hardened lubricants had affected the mechanical operation, and excessive sensitivity in the tracking sensor led to uncontrolled carriage movement after the arm lowered. The solenoid and damper assembly is depicted below: The restoration began by disassembling the mechanism, cleaning all parts, and applying fresh lubrication: A video illustrating the tracking sensor adjustment process is available.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5523): Restoration of the Worn Keypad
item.description: The Beogram 4002 Type 5523 I’m currently working on, like many others, required keypad restoration due to a common issue of a worn-out start key. The keypad’s condition upon arrival is shown in the first image. The second picture showcases the keypad’s appearance after restoration. To avoid damaging the keypad coating through contact with finger oils and friction, we suggest using a soft cloth for operation, regardless of whether it’s restored or original.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5503): Full Restoration
item.description: This document details the restoration of a Beogram 4002 (5503) turntable originating from California. The restoration process commenced with the reconstruction of the carriage and arm lowering mechanisms, encompassing meticulous cleaning and lubrication of components like the solenoid and damper. Following the mechanism restoration, focus shifted to the linkage connecting the damper to the tonearm. This involved addressing a common issue: a detached copper pad on the sensor arm assembly. The pad was reattached using epoxy to ensure smooth operation.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5514): Rebuilding the Arm Lowering Mechanism and the Tracking System
item.description: The Beogram 4002 (5514) I was working on had a completely frozen arm lowering mechanism. The old lubricant had become so hardened that I had to use a screwdriver to pry the linkages off their pivot pins. This is a common issue, easily resolved by cleaning and re-lubricating the mechanism. Here’s a picture of the solenoid, damper, and linkages before disassembly: This image shows the disassembled parts laid out on my workbench:

item.title: Beogram 4000/2/4: Update of Sensor Arm LED Assembly. No More Crumbly Flex-PCB Mess!
item.description: I recently redesigned the sensor arm LED assembly for Beogram 4000, 4002, and 4004 because the prior flexible PCB design was too difficult for some users to install. My new design utilizes a small, rigid PCB that fits perfectly within the bulb housing and includes an insert to ensure accurate LED placement. This ensures the LED sits roughly where the original lightbulb filament was positioned. This image displays the new components:

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Rebuilding the Arm Lowering and Tracking Systems
item.description: My restoration of the Beogram 4002 (5513) began with the arm lowering and tracking systems, as these are essential for any further testing or repair work. To start, I took out the damper and linkages to clean and lubricate them. Thankfully, all the components were in good condition, so lubrication and reassembly were straightforward. Next, I lubricated the pivot point connecting the damper to the arm linkage. This required removing the sensor arm.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Rebuilding the Arm Lowering and Tracking Systems
item.description: Following the repair of the MMC cartridge mount on the Beogram 4000, attention shifted to the malfunctioning arm lowering and tracking mechanisms. The arm lowering system, comprising a solenoid and damper, was examined. The damper and its associated linkages were removed for cleaning and lubrication. Inspection revealed the absence of a vital rubber washer in the damper unit, substituted with a makeshift transparency foil piece. This modification hindered proper damper function.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (Type 5504): Complete Functional Restoration
item.description: This article details the refurbishment of a Beogram 4002 (5504) turntable. An initial assessment of the unit is documented in a previous post here. The turntable, stripped of its panels and platter, appeared relatively untouched. However, evidence of previous work emerged later. The restoration began with the carriage assembly, which was quite dirty. After disassembling and cleaning the parts, the platter motor and capacitors were removed for thorough cleaning. The motor housing, including the bearings, underwent an oil infusion process under vacuum.

item.title: Beogram 4000: An Unusual Keypad PCB
item.description: This article highlights a unique Beogram 4000 keyboard PCB. Typically, the two bulbs illuminating the position scale are wired in series, using two 12V bulbs connected between the 24V power source and ground. This setup is illustrated in the first image and diagram. Notably, this series configuration results in the bulbs having opposite polarity. This polarity difference is ideal for the author’s polarized LED replacement boards. The second image showcases these boards.

item.title: Beogram 4002 Type 5501 from Sweden: Full Technical Restoration and Some Interesting Issues
item.description: I recently acquired a Beogram 4002 turntable (Type 5501 with optical carriage position detection) for a complete technical restoration. The unit arrived without a dust cover. Here’s a picture of the Beogram right after unpacking: Besides a number of loose parts that fell out when I opened the box, I was surprised to see that the cartridge was still mounted on the tonearm: Fortunately, the MMC4000 cartridge had a small plexiglass guard in place, preventing any damage.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Replacement of the Sensor Arm Bulb with an LED and Improvement of the Record Detection Circuit
item.description: Replacing the sensor arm LED is typically the final step in converting a Beogram 4002 to use all LEDs. After restoring the DC motor, the next task was to install a recently designed flex-PCB-based LED assembly to replace the incandescent bulb. The image below shows the sensor arm with the detector assembly removed: Upon zooming in on the full-resolution image, a small black spot is visible on the glass bulb. This spot indicates significant tungsten evaporation from the filament, suggesting the bulb is nearing the end of its life and could soon fail, rendering the Beogram inoperable.

item.title: Beogram 4002: Conversion of the Tracking Sensor Light Bulb to an LED and Adjustment of the Sensor
item.description: I began repairing a Beogram 4002 turntable that I purchased from Craigslist a year ago. I saw it as a good warm-up project before tackling the restoration of my prized Beogram 6000 4-Channel turntable. When I plugged in the Beogram 4002, hoping for the best but prepared for potential issues, nothing happened except for the complete absence of tracking. The tonearm wouldn’t lower, and there were signs of previous repair attempts.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Complete Functional Restoration and Installation of a Beolover Commander Remote Control
item.description: This article details the comprehensive restoration of a Beogram 4002 (5513) turntable. The initial evaluation of this unit is detailed in a separate post. The turntable was first disassembled, revealing the need for bearing lubrication in the platter motor, a common issue in these models. This process typically takes a few days. While the bearings were being re-lubricated, the intricate carriage mechanism, responsible for raising and lowering the tonearm, was addressed.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (Type 5513): Full Functional Restoration and a Test Spin with Stanley Turrentine and Milt Jackson
item.description: This article details the restoration of a Beogram 4002 turntable from Kentucky. The unit, pictured below, was in excellent condition, making it ideal for a complete refurbishment. As is typical with DC motor Beograms, the platter motor was the starting point. These motors commonly suffer from dried-out bearings, leading to speed instability. The extracted motor is shown here: The motor was disassembled to access the bearings: The bearings, visible as two small rings on the black pad, were then submerged in motor oil under a vacuum:

item.title: Beogram 4002 (Type 5513): Complete Functional Restoration and a Spin with the Cal Tjader Quartet!
item.description: This article details the restoration of a Beogram 4002 (5513) turntable. The restoration began with addressing the motor, a common procedure for these models. After removing and disassembling the motor, the Oilite bearings were submerged in oil and placed under a vacuum for several days to replenish lubrication. Next, the carriage and arm mechanisms were disassembled, cleaned, and re-lubricated. This included taking apart and servicing the damper. The main PCB was removed, and both power transistors were replaced.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5503): Replacing the Incandescent Light Bulbs in the RPM Indicators with SMD LED Boards
item.description: The Beogram 4002s model 550x has a unique characteristic: the 33 RPM scale light faintly glows when plugged in, even without pressing start. This is because the 550x models use a different method for switching platter speeds compared to earlier models. Unlike the Beogram 4000 and later DC motor models that use a relay, the 550x utilizes electronic RPM switching, evident by the lack of a relay click when changing speeds.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Replacing the Incandescent Light Bulbs in the RPM Indicators with LEDs
item.description: During the ongoing restoration of a Beogram 4002 (5513) turntable, the incandescent bulbs illuminating the RPM trimmer scales were replaced with LEDs for enhanced longevity. Custom-designed circuit boards housing SMD LEDs were crafted to seamlessly replace the original bulbs, ensuring a direct fit. These LED assemblies are offered to fellow enthusiasts, with an instructional video demonstrating their installation available online. The following images detail the RPM trimmer panel, initially showcasing the rear view with original bulbs in place.

item.title: Beocord 9000: Restoration of the Peak Program Meter with SMD LEDs (II)
item.description: The Beocord 9000’s rebuilt Peak Program Meters (PPM) display passed a 24-hour test, confirming its functionality. To reattach the red-green covers, I secured the display to ensure a tight seal, preventing light leakage. Using a soldering iron, I melted the plastic posts of the covers, replicating the original attachment method. During cleaning, the glue holding the light guide dissolved, indicating it was likely polyvinyl ester-based. I used ‘Aleene’s Original Tacky Glue’ as a substitute, providing a clear and durable bond.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5523): Installation of a LED in the Sensor Arm and Adjustment of the Detection Circuit
item.description: The last incandescent bulb in the Beogram 4002 (5523) being restored was located in the sensor arm. The sensor compartment, with the original bulb, was removed from the arm. A comparison of the original bulb and the replacement LED assembly is shown. The flexible PCB design allows the LED board to be folded and fitted into the compartment. The installed LED emits a warm white light, providing enough red photons to illuminate the red B&O logo on the arm’s front.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Rebuilding the Arm Lowering Mechanism and Linear Tracking System
item.description: My restoration project of a Beogram 4002 (5513) turntable started with the arm lowering and tracking mechanisms. These mechanisms often require attention because of hardened lubricants and misadjusted tracking sensors. After taking the mechanism apart for cleaning and lubrication, I addressed the linkage connecting the damper to the tonearm, which commonly experiences stiffness due to hardened lubricants. The sensor arm was then removed for disassembly to further work on the linkage.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5501): Sensor Arm Light Bulb Replacement - Final Version
item.description: This post follows up on my previous writing about replacing incandescent sensor arm bulbs in Beogram 4002 turntables with LEDs. I’ve found that the LED PCB is best positioned 2.5 mm deep in the sensor compartment’s bulb cavity. This maximizes sensor response, likely because light bulb filaments sit slightly lower than the bulb’s rim. For a consistent solution, I designed a 3D-printed wedge that affixes to the flexPCB with epoxy and positions the LED at the optimal depth.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Replacement of the Sensor Arm Bulb with a LED Assembly
item.description: Following the replacement of the damaged MMC cartridge mount in the Beogram 4000 restoration, the next step was to switch out the last incandescent bulb with an LED replacement. The image displays the bulb housing removed from the sensor arm. The underside of the small PCB and its wiring are shown here: Constructed on a flexible printed circuit board, the LED module is designed to mimic the energy consumption of the original light bulb, preventing any issues with the Beogram’s control system (which verifies if the bulb is working).

item.title: Beogram 4000: Replacing the Light Bulbs in the Control Panel and Gold Plating of the Keypad Contact Terminals
item.description: The next stage of restoring my Beogram 4000 involved working on the control panel. Typically, I swap out the old incandescent bulbs for LEDs and clean the keypad’s contacts. This particular unit had three out of four bulbs burnt out, highlighting the wisdom of switching to LEDs for their superior lifespan. I had recently designed SMD LED boards to replace the position scale illumination bulbs (the top two) and had them professionally manufactured.

item.title: Beogram 4002: Replacing the Detector Arm Light Bulb, Discussion of the Circuit and Relevant Oscilloscope Traces
item.description: A newly acquired Beogram 4002 turntable required a light bulb replacement in its detector arm. Despite the straightforward nature of the bulb replacement, positioning it correctly to ensure proper functionality can be challenging. A video documenting the process illustrates the installation steps, the adjustment of the bulb’s position, and relevant circuit components. Additionally, it showcases oscilloscope readings from a functioning detector setup. High-resolution images provide further insights from the oscilloscope:

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Test Drive with Herbie Hancock (Secrets)
item.description: I’m thrilled to share that I just got my hands on a nearly perfect copy of Herbie Hancock’s 1976 album “Secrets.” It’s in such great condition, it practically looks untouched! This album holds a special place in my heart, especially the track “People Music” with its captivating atmospheric interludes and those classic 70s analog synthesizer sounds, likely created on a “Maestro Universal Synthesizer System.” To celebrate, I decided to listen to the record on my newly restored Beogram 4002(5513) turntable, which is temporarily hooked up to my Beomaster 6000 4-Channel receiver for testing.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Completing the Restoration
item.description: During the summer of 2019, I had the opportunity to work on a Beogram 4002 turntable from Virginia, specifically restoring its DC platter motor. I recently received the entire unit for a complete overhaul. The arm lowering mechanism had been previously restored and was in excellent condition. My attention turned to the remaining areas needing restoration. To begin, I tackled the main PCB. The first photo illustrates its original condition:

item.title: Beogram 4000: Replacement of Sensor Arm Bulb with an LED Assembly
item.description: The last remaining bulb to be replaced with an LED in this Beogram 4000 was the one in the sensor arm. A new flexPCB assembly with a warm-white LED was designed to fit within the sensor arm’s bulb compartment. This particular Beogram 4000 model has a sensor arm with a socket connection for the bulb/sensor compartment. This convenient design allowed for simple removal of the entire assembly, making the LED conversion a benchtop task.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Replacing the Light Bulb of the Tracking Sensor with a Drop-In LED Assembly
item.description: During the restoration of a Beogram 400x turntable, it’s common to replace the tracking sensor’s incandescent bulb with a more durable LED assembly. A drop-in replacement for the Beogram 4002 and 4004 models has been created and documented, while the Beogram 4000 version incorporates a Bang & Olufsen-specified intensity trimmer for fine-tuning the tracking feedback system’s sensitivity. It’s crucial to recalibrate the tracking sensor’s position after any light source replacement to maintain accurate tracking sensitivity.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Replacement of the Tracking Sensor Light Bulb with an SMD LED Light Source and Adjustment of the Feedback Sensisitivy
item.description: This Beogram 4002 turntable had a damaged part (the tracking sensor aperture) that was bent and obstructing the arm’s movement. This issue prevented the tracking system from working correctly. The initial setup used an incandescent light bulb: Upon removing the bulb housing, it was evident that the aperture was bent and rubbing against the optical sensor housing: The aperture was carefully straightened, and the bulb assembly was replaced with a new SMD LED light source.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Complete Restoration and a Test Spin with Oscar Peterson
item.description: I recently obtained a Beogram 4000 turntable from Sweden in very corroded condition. To address the extensive corrosion, I chose to use another 4000 unit as a donor for parts. The donor unit, while missing some components, was free of corrosion. My restoration process started with the carriage. I disassembled and cleaned the arm lowering system, damper, carriage rods, and spindle in an ultrasonic bath. Additionally, the sensor arm assembly was removed to lubricate the damper-to-arm linkage pivot point.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5501): Replacing the Sensor Arm Bulb with a SMD LED on a FlexPCB
item.description: This post details the successful development of an LED-based replacement for the incandescent bulb in the Beogram 4002’s sensor arm. This upgrade was particularly challenging due to the limited space within the arm and the need to replicate the look of the original incandescent light while effectively illuminating the B&O logo. Initial attempts using high-brightness amber LEDs paired with a red LED proved unsatisfactory as the resulting light was too orange and the red LED’s output was weak.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Restoration of the Keypad Cluster
item.description: Following the repair of the Beogram 4000’s electrolytic capacitors and AC motor, the focus shifted to restoring the keypad cluster. The circuitry underneath the keypad forms the Beogram’s control system, a pioneering digital system utilizing TTL logic chips. This system relies heavily on inputs from numerous mechanical switches within the turntable to make decisions. The keypad itself houses eight of these switches, allowing user interaction. The keypad was held by a single screw, which was missing, hinting at previous tampering.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Full Functional Restoration and a Test Spin with the Bill Evans Trio
item.description: This article details the restoration of a Beogram 4000 turntable from a Massachusetts customer. The initial evaluation can be found here. The restoration began by addressing the carriage system. This involved cleaning hardened lubricants from various parts like the arm lowering mechanism, rods, spindle, linkages, and damper, and applying modern synthetic lubricants. A key aspect of the Beogram 4000 is its solenoid-activated switches, which frequently experience oxidation and require attention. The contact terminals were removed and re-plated with nickel and gold-cobalt alloy for optimal performance and corrosion resistance.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Restoration of Arm Lowering and Tracking Systems
item.description: The initial phase of the Beogram 4000 restoration involved the arm’s lowering and tracking mechanisms. The solenoid and damper, essential for the arm’s smooth and controlled descent onto the record, were revealed. Each part was carefully removed, cleaned, and lubricated. Attention then turned to the linkage connecting the damper plunger to the tonearm. Located on the sensor arm’s side, it required the arm’s removal to access and lubricate the linkage’s pivot point.
